title: Everyday Activities: Speak About Your Day with Confidence
subtitle: Basic phrases and vocabulary for daily life activities in American English

overview.description: In this lesson, learners will explore common daily activities and practice simple phrases used in everyday American English conversations. The focus is on building vocabulary and sentence structures that help learners describe their routines and understand others with ease.
objectives: Identify and use 8-10 common daily activity vocabulary words
Form simple present tense sentences describing daily routines
Ask and answer basic questions about daily activities
Understand and use time expressions related to daily life
Build confidence in speaking about personal daily activities
prerequisites: Basic knowledge of English alphabet and pronunciation
Familiarity with simple greetings and introductions
Understanding of basic present tense verb forms (I am, you are)
keySkills: Cultural awareness of American daily life

warmUp.title: Daily Activity Brainstorm
warmUp.activity: Students quickly name activities they do every day in their own language or English if possible. This warms up their thinking about daily routines and prepares them for vocabulary learning.
instructions: Ask students to think about what they do every day from morning to night.
Have students say or write down as many activities as they can in one minute.
Share some examples aloud as a class.
Introduce the idea that today’s lesson will help them talk about these activities in English.

presentation.introduction: Daily life activities are part of everyone's routine, and talking about them helps you connect with others in everyday American settings. Today, we will learn key words and simple phrases to describe what you do during your day—from waking up to going to bed.

mainContent.content: We will learn words for common activities like waking up, eating breakfast, going to work or school, cooking, watching TV, and going to bed. These words help you describe your day clearly.

examples.explanation: Simple present tense to talk about routine.

tips: Use simple present tense to talk about routines.
Say the time using ‘at’ + time for specific activities.
Practice pronunciation of activity verbs ending in -ing for ongoing actions.

mainContent.content: Learn how to ask about daily activities politely and give short, clear answers. For example, 'What do you do in the morning?' and 'I go to work.'

examples.sentence: What do you do after school?
examples.explanation: Question using 'do' to ask about routines.

examples.sentence: I watch TV in the evening.
examples.explanation: Short answer with subject + verb + time phrase.

tips: Use question words like 'What' and 'When' to learn about others’ routines.
Answer with full sentences to practice grammar and vocabulary.

visualAids: Picture chart of daily activities with images showing waking up, eating, working, playing, and sleeping.
Clock images to practice telling time and associating activities with specific times.
Simple conversation bubbles with sample questions and answers.

vocabulary.definition: To stop sleeping and become awake
vocabulary.example: I wake up at 6 a.m. every day.

vocabulary.definition: To put food in your mouth and chew it
To travel to your job or place of employment
vocabulary.example: He goes to work by bus.

vocabulary.definition: To learn or review information, often at school
To look at a television program
vocabulary.example: I watch TV in the evening.

vocabulary.definition: To prepare food by heating it
To make something free of dirt
vocabulary.example: We clean the house on weekends.
I go to bed at 10 p.m.

grammar.focus: Simple Present Tense for Daily Routines
grammar.explanation: We use the simple present tense to talk about habits, routines, and facts. For most verbs, we add -s or -es for he/she/it in the positive form.
grammar.formula: Subject + base verb (I/you/we/they) OR Subject + verb + s/es (he/she/it)

examples.explanation: Add -s for he/she/it in simple present.
'I' always uses the base verb without -s.

exceptions: Use 'do' or 'does' for questions and negatives.

exercises.instructions: Choose the correct verb form for the sentence.

questions.question: She ___ breakfast at 7 a.m.
questions.explanation: For 'she', add -s to the verb in simple present.

exercises.instructions: Complete the sentences with the correct form of the verb in parentheses.
Match the activity with the correct time phrase.

questions.question: Match each activity to when it usually happens.

exercises.instructions: Choose the best answer to complete the question.

questions.question: ___ do you wake up?
questions.explanation: 'When' is used to ask about time.

exercises.instructions: Write the correct form of the verb and time phrase.

questions.question: I ___ (go) to bed ___ 10 p.m.
questions.explanation: 'I go' is simple present; use 'at' before specific times.

questions.question: ___ she watch TV after dinner?
questions.explanation: 'Does' is used with he/she/it in questions.

exercises.instructions: Complete with the correct verb form.
Match the question to the correct answer.

questions.question: Match the questions with answers.
options: What time do you wake up?

interactiveActivities.name: Daily Routine Role-Play
interactiveActivities.description: Students pair up and ask each other about their daily routines using learned vocabulary and simple present tense.
steps: Review question and answer phrases as a class.
In pairs, take turns asking 'What do you do in the morning?' and similar questions.
Answer using complete sentences, e.g., 'I eat breakfast at 8 a.m.'
Share some dialogues with the class.
materials: Role-play cards with questions and time prompts
Visual daily routine chart for reference

speakingTask.title: Describe Your Daily Routine
speakingTask.description: Students will speak for 1-2 minutes describing their own daily activities using vocabulary and simple present tense.
prompts: What time do you wake up?
What do you eat for breakfast?
Do you go to work or school?
What do you do in the evening?
What time do you go to bed?
evaluationCriteria: Use of simple present tense verbs correctly
Accurate use of daily activity vocabulary

writingTask.title: My Daily Activities Paragraph
writingTask.description: Write a short paragraph describing your daily routine using at least 5 vocabulary words from today’s lesson.
writingTask.prompt: Write about what you do every day from morning to night. Use simple sentences and time phrases.
evaluationCriteria: Inclusion of vocabulary words related to daily activities

keyPoints: Simple present tense is used for daily routines and habits.
Add -s or -es for he, she, it in positive sentences.
Use question words like 'What' and 'When' to ask about activities.
Common daily activities vocabulary helps describe routines clearly.
Practice speaking and writing helps build confidence.

commonMistakes.mistake: She go to work at 8 a.m.
commonMistakes.correction: She goes to work at 8 a.m.
commonMistakes.explanation: Add -es for 'she' in simple present tense.
Use 'do' for questions in simple present.

Interview a partner about their daily routine and report back to the class.
Create a daily schedule chart using American time formats (12-hour clock with a.m./p.m.).
extension.realWorldApplication: Talking about your daily activities helps you make friends, join conversations, and manage appointments in American settings such as school, work, or community events.
extension.culturalNotes: In American culture, sharing your daily routine is a common way to build connections and small talk. Americans often ask about work, meals, and free time to learn more about others.
